title: 10 Easy Tips For Sticking To Your New Year's Resolutions
summary: There are many common New Yearâ€™s resolutions with a focus on habit-building, like exercising more, eating healthier, reading more or learning new skills. Starting small and building up slowly is a better way to go about it. Celebrate small wins, even if they seem insignificant at the time, and the more consistent you are with your efforts, the better the results will be. It takes time to change your habits, and you don't want to throw in the towel too soon.

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"New Year\u2019s resolutions are like a clean slate for the coming year. What you do with that opportunity is up to you. Maybe you resolve to eat healthier, exercise more or reduce stress and anxiety. Maybe you decide to learn a new skill, read more books, help others or travel more. Or maybe your resolution is to do something completely different \u2014 like learn a language, stop procrastinating or read the complete works of Shakespeare. The possibilities are endless, but sticking to those resolutions can be challenging. The key is establishing habits that will last all 365 days of the year and not just one crazy day in January. It takes small but deliberate changes in everyday life that add up over time and become second nature. Here are 10 easy tips for sticking to your New Year\u2019s resolutions:"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

content.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("h2",null,"Change your environment"),mdx("p",null,"Changing your environment is a subtle shift, but it can make a difference. Start by shifting your daily routine, especially if you\u2019re a person who is stuck in a daily routine that doesn\u2019t support your New Year\u2019s resolutions. If you\u2019re trying to eat healthier, you might want to consider a different grocery store or a different route home from work that gives you a different perspective. If you\u2019re trying to reduce stress and anxiety, you might want to change where you go to unwind and relax. If you go to the same place every day, you\u2019ll likely get used to it and it won\u2019t have the same effect. If you\u2019re trying to exercise more, you might want to consider a different time or day of the week. If you usually work out on a Wednesday night, try switching to a Saturday morning. If you\u2019re trying to learn a new skill, you might want to find a new place to practice \u2014 like a new coffee shop or library."),mdx("h2",null,"Write down your reasons"),mdx("p",null,"This works well for resolutions that are more about personal growth and self-awareness. If you\u2019re trying to reduce stress and anxiety, write down why that is important to you. If you\u2019re trying to read more books, write down why reading is important. If you\u2019re trying to help others more, write down why doing so is important to you. If you\u2019re trying to be more creative, write down how creativity makes you feel. If you\u2019re trying to spend more time with loved ones, write down how those relationships make you feel."),mdx("h2",null,"Make it a habit"),mdx("p",null,"There are many common New Year\u2019s resolutions with a focus on habit-building, like exercising more, eating healthier, reading more or learning new skills. Those are great to focus on, but they can also be overwhelming. It\u2019s better to look at one habit at a time and make it a part of your daily routine. Once you have that down, you can add another habit. If you try to do too much at once, it\u2019s likely you will burn out and give up. Starting small and building up slowly is a better way to go about it. If you\u2019re trying to read more, don\u2019t go from reading zero books a year to 12 books a month. Start with one book a month and build up from there. If you\u2019re trying to eat healthier, start by making one small change \u2014 like switching from white bread to whole grain bread or drinking more water. Then add a second change, and so on. If you\u2019re trying to exercise more, start with something low impact, like walking, and gradually increase the amount you do over time."),mdx("h2",null,"Celebrate small wins"),mdx("p",null,"You\u2019re bound to hit roadblocks along the way, and that\u2019s perfectly normal. Try to celebrate small wins, even if they seem insignificant at the time. If you\u2019re trying to read more, don\u2019t get frustrated if you only read one book in a month. If you\u2019re trying to eat healthier, don\u2019t get discouraged if you only stick to your new eating habits for a week. If you\u2019re trying to reduce stress and anxiety, don\u2019t get discouraged if you feel like you\u2019re not making progress. It takes time to change your habits, and you don\u2019t want to throw in the towel too soon. Be patient and consistent, and those habits will become second nature."),mdx("h2",null,"Set realistic expectations"),mdx("p",null,"It\u2019s important to set realistic expectations. If you\u2019re trying to eat healthier, don\u2019t expect to change your eating habits overnight. It takes time and patience to change your eating habits for the better. If you\u2019re trying to exercise more, don\u2019t expect to go from never exercising to training for a marathon. Start with walking or yoga and build up from there. If you\u2019re trying to read more, don\u2019t expect to read 12 books in a month. Start with one book a month and build up from there. If you\u2019re trying to reduce stress and anxiety, don\u2019t expect to change your habits overnight. These things take time, and the more consistent you are with your efforts, the better the results will be."),mdx("h2",null,"Don\u2019t forget to breathe and be in the moment"),mdx("p",null,"It\u2019s easy to get caught up in pursuing your resolutions and forget to just be in the moment. If you\u2019re trying to reduce stress and anxiety, don\u2019t forget to be in the moment. If you\u2019re trying to read more, don\u2019t forget to be in the moment. If you\u2019re trying to eat healthier, don\u2019t forget to be in the moment. All three of those resolutions require you to be in the moment, and that\u2019s the best way to reduce stress and anxiety. If you\u2019re always thinking about what you need to do next and what you did yesterday, it\u2019s easy to get stressed out and anxious. If you\u2019re trying to spend more time with loved ones, don\u2019t forget to be in the moment. Put your phone down and be there with your loved ones."),mdx("h2",null,"Commit to being better, not perfect"),mdx("p",null,"This is especially important for resolutions that are more about self-awareness and personal growth. If you\u2019re trying to reduce stress and anxiety, don\u2019t try to be perfect. If you\u2019re trying to read more, don\u2019t try to be perfect. If you\u2019re trying to help others more, don\u2019t try to be perfect. If you\u2019re trying to be more creative, don\u2019t try to be perfect. You\u2019ll only set yourself up for failure. Instead, commit to being better through daily and consistent effort. The results will be much better than if you try to be perfect. You\u2019ll learn and grow as you go, and in the end, you\u2019ll be better than you were before."),mdx("h2",null,"Don\u2019t let fear sway your decisions"),mdx("p",null,"Fear is normal, but it can also be paralyzing and hinder your progress. If you\u2019re trying to reduce stress and anxiety, don\u2019t let fear sway your decisions. If you\u2019re trying to read more, don\u2019t let fear sway your decisions. If you\u2019re trying to eat healthier, don\u2019t let fear sway your decisions. If you\u2019re trying to help others more, don\u2019t let fear sway your decisions. If you\u2019re trying to be more creative, don\u2019t let fear sway your decisions. If you\u2019re pursuing any New Year\u2019s resolutions, don\u2019t let fear sway your decisions. Be confident in your decisions and know that the best way to reduce stress and anxiety is to be in the moment."),mdx("h2",null,"Conclusion"),mdx("p",null,"The key to successfully sticking to your New Year\u2019s resolutions is to make small but deliberate changes in everyday life that add up over time and become second nature. It\u2019s important to be patient and consistent, and those habits will become a part of your daily routine. It\u2019s also helpful to start small and build up slowly as it\u2019s easier to build and maintain momentum when you start small. It\u2019s important to note that not all New Year\u2019s resolutions are created equal. Some are better suited to long-term change while others are better suited to"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: What Are the Drawbacks of Mediation?

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:t,...e}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...e,components:t,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Mediation is a great option for resolving disputes and reducing the stress of a legal conflict. It\u2019t also less expensive than going to court and doesn\u2019t give your opponent any negative information that could be used against you in the future. The only potential drawback to mediation is that it requires both parties to agree on an outcome they are happy with. If one party feels like they have no other options, they may not be willing to mediate. However, this should not stop you from exploring this option further.
Mediation has many benefits over other methods of dispute resolution, such as negotiation and arbitration. However, every type of settlement has its drawbacks. Read on to learn more about the pros and cons of mediation as a dispute resolution technique:`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Train Your Dog to Leave It

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:t,...e}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...e,components:t,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Perhaps the most frustrating thing about owning a dog is that your house can never really be your own again. Fussing and fuming won\u2019t make them any less likely to follow you anywhere, or to notice that bag of chips you just carelessly threw on the table. Dogs are dogs, which means they will follow your slightest lead and chip in with their two cents at every opportunity. Sadly, this also means that it\u2019s not uncommon for dogs to get into things they shouldn\u2019t. You like peace and quiet? Not so much when there\u2019s a dog around. You like keeping your things? Good luck with that.
But luckily, with some bit of training and persistence, you can teach your pup exactly what\u2019s off limits and exactly where to leave it instead. Best of all, all these tricks take very little time and effort on our part. It doesn\u2019t have to be hard! Let\u2019s check out how!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: Adopting a Pet and What to Know about Australian Labradoodles

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Adopting a pet from an animal shelter is a great way to bring love and companionship into your home. It\u2019t also a kind and selfless act, as you are giving another creature a second chance at life. However, adopting a pet can be quite the ordeal. You must first understand the ins and outs of owning pets, choose whether you want to adopt an adult or juvenile animal, narrow down your selection of potential pets by checking their housing requirements, veterinarian references and character traits, and finally interview prospective pets before bringing them home with you.
There are many different types of animals that you can adopt as a pet. Read on to find out more about adopting an Australian labradoodle as your new pet!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: What Are the Benefits of Mediation for Businesses?
What Are the Benefits of Mediation for Families?

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Mediation is an alternative dispute resolution process. It\u2019s a way of resolving disputes that is less adversarial than litigation and usually cheaper, faster, and more private than other methods. Mediation is also collaborative as well as neutral. The mediator acts as a neutral party who helps the parties attempt to resolve their dispute in a fair and equitable manner.
In mediation, both parties together with their respective attorneys choose from various options to settle the case outside of court. The goal of mediation is to find solutions that are agreeable to both parties. It\u2019s about finding win-win solutions instead of win-lose outcomes. It\u2019s about exploring solutions that may not have been considered had the parties not been under the guidance of a mediator who has no stake in either outcome of the dispute other than seeing it resolved amicably and fairly so that everyone walks away feeling like they have gained something from it rather than having given up something they would rather have kept.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"Mediation is a great way for parties to resolve their disputes in an amicable environment. It is also a less expensive, private and confidential process that can help the parties reach an agreement quickly. While mediation works best when both parties are willing to negotiate and compromise, it does not always work out that way in real life. Some cases require the help of a neutral third-party who can guide the parties towards coming to a settlement agreement based on fair grounds. A neutral third party known as a mediator will not take sides and instead help both parties find common ground so they can reach an agreement without going to court or any other type of resolution process. So if you are involved in a dispute and want to avoid the stress, expense, and time consuming legal proceedings while keeping your relationship with your family members intact then mediation may be right for you"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
